blow this is chef john from food wishes
comm live eggplant bacon that's right we
really should have called this bacon
flavored eggplant but quite frankly
eggplant bacon will get more hits so
it's a little bit of a compromise we put
the word bacon in quotations which I
believe means that can't be sued again
but forget about what we're calling this
the important thing to focus on here is
how surprisingly well this came out and
no not really is a bacon substitute but
really more of a fun delicious way to
eat eggplant so with that let's go ahead
and get started with what I'm going to
call the bacon brine and this is
basically going to contain the same
things to turn pork into bacon which are
of course salt sugar and smoke for our
salty elements we're going to start with
something called tamari which is a
beautiful type of soy sauce
it's made with 100% soy beans instead of
the usual combination of soybean and
wheat but anyway we'll do some tamari or
soy sauce and then we're also going to
add a little splash of Worcestershire
sauce and that's pretty much going to
take care of our salty which brings us
to our sweets and as far as the sugar
goes in this we're going to go with some
maple syrup and normally at this point I
would tell you to use grade-b but
apparently that's not a thing anymore
now it's called something like grade-a
robust but either way we'll go ahead and
add some maple syrup before seasoning
this up with a very generous amount of
freshly ground black pepper will also
sneak in a little picture garlic powder
as well as a nice big spoon of smoked
paprika and then for a little bit of
heat which is always neat we'll add a
pinch of cayenne then we'll take a whisk
and go ahead and give that a mix and
then what we're going to do next is
introduce a couple tablespoons of olive
oil but we want it to sort of multiply
in which means we want to kind of
drizzle it in slowly while whisking and
to make that easier what we sometimes do
is make a little ring out of our towel
and what that does is help keep that
bowls table so we can whisk with one
hand while drizzling our olive oil in
with the other and we don't have to
worry about that bowl moving around too
much so we'll go ahead and whisk in a
couple tablespoons of oil as shown and
then last but not least one optional
ingredients a little bit of liquid smoke
if you want so I am going to dump in a
little bit because I do think it makes
it taste more like bacon but be very
careful that stuff can be overpowering
so if we're using it will mix in a
little bit of that at which point we can
set that aside and start in on prepping
our eggplant in preference to may know
we can identify by checking the mark
where the flower was attached and what
we're looking for is a small dot versus
a long slot and what that indicates is
that you're dealing with what they call
a mallaig plant which is going to have a
lot less seeds and what we'll do to prep
this is go ahead and cut off the end and
then we will cut this in quarters before
slicing then hopefully approximately the
same thickness as a slice of bacon
before this operation I highly recommend
one of these vegetable slicers yes you
do have one you probably forgot about it
it's in the pantry somewhere so if you
don't already have one of these
mandatory pieces of equipment I would
say this recipe is the perfect excuse to
get one so I'm gonna go ahead and slice
up that eggplant which is super easy on
one of these things it's also super easy
to slice off your fingertips so be
careful and theoretically use the finger
guard which of course I always do and
then all we have to do once our eggplant
is sliced is simply dip it into our
mixture making sure it's thoroughly
coated and then maybe wiping off a
little busy excess before transferring
it onto a parchment paper lined baking
sheet and by the way even though I stole
this recipe this is my big improvement
on the method because all the other
techniques for this I saw calls for
brushing our mixture onto the eggplant
which I did the first time I made this
and it took forever so I thought to
myself they're trippin I should be
dipping which by the way is exactly how
that thought popped into my head but
anyway that's going to be up to you you
are after all the Swizz Beatz of your
faux meats
now speaking of on to the next one once
we have our slices dipped and arranged
on our sheet pans we're going to go
ahead and transfer that into a 225
degree oven for in my case 45 minutes
which according to most online recipe
should be enough time for this to be
done in crispy but it's not after 45
minutes they were still very soft so
what I decided to do because I still had
a little bit of our bacon brine in a
bowl was give those a little extra
brushing and then I went ahead and put
those back in the oven but this time it
250 mostly because I was getting
impatient which by the way is probably
how I'll start them next time and we'll
continue at 250 until the egg pine is
crisp and very bacon like and I would
say that it's not a bad idea that at
some point during the cooking time
you pull these out and flip them over
and above and beyond that once you get
towards the end of the cooking be
careful because some are going to finish
before others see I think this one was a
little thinner than the other slices and
even though the other ones were still a
little bit soft this one seemed crispy
and ready to enjoy so that's what I did
and how was it actually I'd rather not
say we're not doing the official tasting
yet so I popped those back in until
those pieces got nice and crisp and
looks something like this check it out
I'm always blown away by how similar
this smells and looks to bacon so I
think this stuff more than passes the
nose and I test but what about the taste
well that's where we have to talk about
your expectations if you take a bite of
this and think of it as a replacement
for bacon you'll probably be a little
disappointed since it's a vegetable in
that pork it clearly will not taste
exactly like bacon why despite that it
does have a bacon ish flavor and is very
enjoyable to eat so I think it's a
mistake to think of this stuff is
something you'd eat instead of bacon the
way you really should be thinking about
this stuff is it it's something to eat
instead of eggplant but of course since
we are calling it bacon even though it's
in quotations I needed to test it with
some eggs and I'm very happy to report
it work quite nicely I mean since I'm
not allowed to eat bread anymore
I usually dip my bacon into the eggs and
this worked out almost as nicely except
it wasn't bacon which is we just
discussed is fine
remember we're not trying to replace

to replace eggplant with eggplant bacon
okay oh and in case you're wondering how
